summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from October to November 2021 between attorneys from WilmerHale (representing JPMorgan) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails discuss scheduling calls and coordinating the identification and subpoena of a JPMorgan witness for Maxwell's trial.

persons.name: Allison Stoddart
persons.context: Attorney from WilmerHale representing JPMorgan, coordinating with the U.S. Attorney's Office to schedule calls and arrange for a JPMorgan witness for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

persons.context: Mentioned as a participant for a scheduled call between the defense and prosecution teams regarding the trial witness.

persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York corresponding with defense counsel about trial witness coordination and subpoenas.

persons.name: Lara
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York copied on correspondence regarding trial witness coordination.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell

Stoddart (defense counsel for JPMorgan) corresponds with AUSA Maurene (prosecution) to coordinate a trial witness and subpoena.

events.title: Request for trial appearance subpoena
events.description: Allison Stoddart requests the U.S. Attorney's Office to provide JPMorgan with a trial appearance subpoena for a witness.

events.title: Prosecution sends draft exhibits
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sends draft exhibits to facilitate conversation about identifying a JPMorgan witness for the Maxwell trial.

keyFacts: JPMorgan Chase, represented by WilmerHale attorneys, was coordinating with the U.S. Attorney's Office to provide a witness for the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal trial in late 2021.
The prosecution requested a broadly worded subpoena to JPMorgan to secure a trial witness, indicating the bank's potential involvement or knowledge relevant to the case.
Email correspondence shows active scheduling and coordination between defense and prosecution attorneys in the weeks leading up to Maxwell's trial.
The document references the case 'United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN)', confirming it pertains to her federal criminal prosecution.
The correspondence involves multiple Assistant U.S. Attorneys (Maurene and Lara) from the Southern District of New York working on witness coordination.
